title: Lem/Leme

common.text:
### Beyond Historical Books

When we examine certain historical books, we frequently notice a tendency to highlight figures deemed "relevant" ,such as kings and political leaders. However, a king cannot win a war alone. In many cases, he lacks the financial resources required to achieve his goals. In this text, we will explore the trajectory of a family whose origins trace back to Bugres, continuing through Portugal, and eventually arriving in Brazil. While some of their actions may have been considered secondary at the time, they were, in reality, pivotal.

#### Historical Perspectives

The previous paragraph might give the mistaken impression that this text intends to overlook the flaws of the individuals discussed. That is not the case. Furthermore, we do not aim to cover every aspect of their history. For a more detailed exploration, we encourage readers to consult the sources cited.

### The First Generations

In studying the early generations of the Leme family, it is common to encounter discrepancies among authors. Generations for which there is no documentary evidence will be presented as hypothetical. Conversely, those supported by solid documentation will be treated as established theory.

maps.text: Movement of part of Lem family during a period of 150 years.

prerequisites: The mathematical operations presented on this page are based on the concept of mathematical equality (History Tracers Team, , Are we trully equal?).

families.name: Descendants of the Lem Family in Bruges

history.text:
### Lem in Bruges

This text outlines the first three generations of the Lem family, though it is possible they could be represented as only two
The information about Willem Lem is limited and does not originate from primary sources. Nevertheless, the available data serves as a basis for understanding the subsequent generations
She passed away in , according to records by Jean-Jacques Gailliard, corroborated by the Lem Family Association
The information about Maertin Lem's mother is based on ancient texts that do not constitute primary sources, on the other hand, his father is confirmed for a donation

The information about Maertin Lem (I) is limited. It is certain that he was born before <htdate0>, or at the latest in that year, which marks the death of his mother. He is also mentioned in a donation recorded at the Church of Sint Jacob on <htdate1>

André Clayes presents an interpretation slightly different from that of Jean-Jacques Gailliard, suggesting that this generation could be the same as the next. In discussions with the Lem Family Association, we were informed that this conclusion likely originates from the Anales de Flandes, though no documentation exists to substantiate it. There is no evidence to support either the merging of these generations or the alleged marriage to the Barroso family. As a result, we have opted to omit Jeanne’s surname
This information is based on ancient texts that do not constitute primary sources.
This information is based on ancient texts that do not constitute primary sources.

According to discussions with the Lem Family Association, following a document dated <htdate0>, another mention of Maertin Lem appears only in <htdate1>, where he is recorded as being sent to address issues involving Rombout De Wachtere. This Maertin is possibly the grandson of Maertin Lem (I), not his son. This hypothesis is supported by documentation of a Maertin Lem’s activities in Bruges between <htdate2> and <htdate3>, the year of his death

source.text: Brugge Stands Archief, Civilen Sententiën-> Vierschaar (157) - >1465 - 1469 deel 1, fl. 24v, 55v, 66, 74, 83, 85v, 87 - 89, 91v - 93v

history.text: However, the absence of contemporaneous documentation registering all events with precision leads to divergent opinions. Philippe Garnier suggests that Maertin Leme of Bruges and Maertin Leme of Funchal might be the same person, which would imply that Maertin was the son of Willem Lem, effectively eliminating an intermediate generation

In addition to his business ventures, Maertin Lem (II) played an active role in Portuguese expansion. This involvement may have earned him—or his son of the same name—a coat of arms, recorded in the Livro do Armeiro Mor. This honor was also granted to one of his sons, António Leme, and might have influenced Rui Leme’s role as a witness to the Treaty of Tordesillas. Both events are discussed in greater detail later
Figure 2: Arms of Maertim Lem (do Cró, João, , f. 110v (img .236)).

During historical periods of persecution against Jewish communities, Maertin Lem appears in a document related to Christian justice. According to the chancellery of Afonso V, Maertin authorized his Jewish creditors to be subjected to Christian courts

source.text: Chancelaria Régia, Afonso V, Livro 8, fl. 63v (img. 98)
Paes Leme, Margarida O. R., pp. 48

history.text: In terms of his personal life, records from Afonso V’s chancellery indicate that Maertin legitimized his children with Leonor Rodrigues, suggesting the absence of a formal marriage between them. It is also possible that he married Adrienne Van Nieuwenhove upon returning to Bruges, depending on the interpretation chosen regarding his personal life

source.text: Chancelaria Régia, Afonso V, Livro 8, fl. 67 (img. 104)

history.text: Legitimized according to Afonso V’s chancellery

source.text: Chancelaria Régia, Afonso V, Livro 8, fl. 67 (img. 104)

families.name: Descendants of Maertin Lem and Leonor Rodrigues

history.text: This section highlights part of the history of the children of Maertin Lem and Leonor Rodrigues, as recorded in the Chancellery of King Alfonso V

source.text: Chancelaria Régia, Afonso V, Livro 8, fl. 67 (img. 104)

history.text: According to researcher Philippe Garnier, Martim Leme was the same individual who lived in Funchal. This hypothesis suggests that his father, Maertin Lem, did not return to Bruges

However, André L. Fr. Clayes disagrees with this interpretation. In his view, Martim Leme was born in Bruges. This perspective contradicts the legitimation recorded in Portugal but aligns with the hypothesis presented by Emanuel Sueyro
Despite these differing views, both researchers agree that Martim Leme married Adrienne Van Nieuwenhove
Research by Philippe Garnier and André L. Fr. Clayes
Rui Leme received a knighthood during the reign of Dom Manuel I

source.text: Chancelaria Régia, Manuel I, Livro 28, fl. 110 (img. 180)

history.text: Although little is known about his personal life, Rui Leme is remembered as one of the witnesses to the Treaty of Tordesillas, a pivotal historical event that leads us to Reflection 2

source.text: Biblioteca Nacional de Portugal - BNP, BN MS. 5, n.º 25, F. 6r

history.text:
Figure 3: Page from the Tratado de Tordesillas mentioning Rui Leme (Biblioteca Nacional de Portugal - BNP, BN MS. 5, n.º 25, F. 6r). ).

Reflection 2: On Land Division

Imagine a scenario where a group of people gathers for a meeting and decides to divide the world among themselves, claiming ownership of everything that has been built over millennia. Would you feel comfortable with the idea of being left with nothing?

The Treaty of Tordesillas represented a similar initiative. It divided not only lands recently discovered by Europeans but also territories they were unaware of at the time, without consulting the native inhabitants

Antonio Leme lived during the 15th century, according to the Gregorian calendar. However, it is only in the 20th century, through research efforts such as those by Luiz P. M. de Castro, that his history and the legacy of his descendants in Brazil began to be properly understood

source.text: de Castro, Luiz P. M., pp. 4-9

history.text: Like his father, Antonio Leme was awarded a coat of arms in recognition of his contributions to the Portuguese conquest of Tangier

source.text: Chancelaria Régia, Afonso V, Livro 21, fl. 90 (img. 173)
de Castro, Luiz P. M., pp. 15-16

history.text: Figure 4: Arms of Antonio Leme (do Cró, João, , f. 110v (img .236)).

In addition to Rui Leme, Antonio Leme also experienced the Iberian expansion, though from a different perspective. A chronicle recounts that he had a meeting with Christopher Columbus, during which they discussed three islands Antonio claimed to have sighted while navigating

Mathematics in History

Antonio Romeu de Armas, when writing about the meeting between Antônio Leme and Christopher Columbus, mentions a distance of "one hundred leguas" (cien leguas). But what would this distance be in kilometers?

The legua is a unit of length whose value varies depending on the historical period and the region in which it was used. For this study, we will use the itinerant legua, commonly employed to describe travel distances, which is equivalent to 5.5 kilometers (History Tracers Team, , Atlas, Coordinates of Surface ; Garza Martínez, V. ).

Starting with the relationship:

1 legua ∝ 5.5 kilometers (F. 1)

To convert leguas to kilometers, we must transform this proportionality into equality, which can be done using a proportionality constant (Weisstein, Eric W.). Two constants will be defined: a converts kilometers to leguas, while b converts leguas to kilometer.

Defining the constant a: 1 legua = (a) 5.5 kilometers (F. 2)

Multiplying both sides by 1 legua5.5 kilometers:

1 legua5.5 kilometers = a (F. 3)

Constant b:

1 legua (b) = 5.5 kilometers (F. 4)

Multiplying both sides by 5.5 kilometers1 legua:

b = 5.5 kilometers1 legua (F. 5)

With these constants defined, we can use the rule of three to perform the conversions (Stover, Christopher). The rule states:

x y = z w (F. 7)

Where x, z and w are known values, and y, can be calculated multiplying both sides by x>:

y = z wx (F. 8)

We want to determine the distance equivalent of 100 leguas in kilometers. Using (F. 8) and (F. 5), we set z = 5.5 kilometers, x = 1 legua, y, and w = 100 leguas. Substituting these values into (F. 8):

x = 5.5 kilometers1 legua 100 leguas = 550.0 kilometers (F. 9)

Thus, 100 leguas is equivalent to 550 kilometers.

To convert 550 kilometers back to leguas, we use (F. 7). This time, we assign (F. 3): z = 1 legua, x = 5.5 kilometers, and w = 550 kilometers:

x = 1 legua5.5 kilometers 550 kilometers = 100 leguas (F. 10)

In genealogical records, errors have been identified regarding Antonio Leme’s personal life. Brazilian genealogists incorrectly claimed that he married a daughter of Pedro Gonçalves da Câmara. In reality, he married a daughter of Pedro Gonçalves da Clara, as clarified by Henrique Henriques de Noronha. This conclusion was based on a testament discovered on Madeira Island

source.text: de Castro, Luiz P. M., pp. 8 - 9

history.text: Antão Leme arrived in Brazil in <htdate0>, accompanied by his son. Before emigrating, he lived in the city of Lisbon

source.text: Paes Leme, Margarida O. R., pp. 10 - 11

history.text: According to Frei Gaspar Madre de Deus, there is few documentation mentioning Antão Leme. We know he was Ordinary judge when he arrived, and he was also responsible to bring sweet dulce from Madera Island

source.text: Madre de Deus, Gaspar, Frei, pp. 55

history.text: Mentioned in his justification of nobility

source.text: Madre de Deus, Gaspar, Frei, pp. 56-57

history.text: Identified as "Pero" and not "Pedro" in his inventory. For this reason, we use the name "Pero" in this document

According to Frei Gaspar Madre de Deus, Pero Leme had his nobility officially justified, which allowed us to trace his patrilineal lineage within the Lem family. Additionally, Frei Gaspar highlights that Pero had only two documented marriages and was the owner of the Santa Anna farm. Pero passed away in São Paulo, and his testament was approved on <htdate0>

source.text: Madre de Deus, Gaspar, Frei, pp. 56 - 57

history.text: Over a century after his death, part of Pero’s history was reinterpreted by Pedro Dias Paes (Leme), a descendant who sought to claim the same noble title for himself. Pedro alleged that Pero had another son, Fernão Dias Paes, born from a supposed third marriage. However, this claim presents several inconsistencies (de Castro, Luiz P. M., , pp. 12 - 14)

• Pero’s inventory does not mention a wife named Isabel Paes or a son named Fernão Dias Paes (Inventários e Testamentos, , Volume 1, pp. 25-64)
  • Fernão Dias Paes’ wife, Lucrécia Leme, mentions a brother named Braz Esteves in her inventory. This relationship is confirmed in the inventory of her mother, Leonor Leme, which also makes no mention of Fernão Dias Paes as her son or any relationship to him (Inventários e Testamentos, , Volume 14, pp. 316 ; Inventários e Testamentos, , Volume 9, pp. 6-8).
  • A letter from Pedro T. de A. Paes Leme to Frei Gaspar Madre de Deus states that a son of Fernão Dias Paes referred to Pero Leme as his "great-grandfather" (bisavô) instead of his "grandfather" (avô) (Publicação official de documentos interessantes para a historia e costumes de São Paulo ... Vol. 4, , pp. 21-24 ; de Castro, Luiz P. M., , pp. 18-19).
Confirmed in the inventories of Pero Leme and Gracia Rodrigues
Confirmed in the inventories of Pero Leme and Gracia Rodrigues

Isabel Paes is mentioned in a nobility justification presented over a century after Pero's death as part of an attempt to fabricate a patrilineal lineage. However, there are no primary sources supporting this hypothesis

source.text: de Castro, Luiz P. M., pp. 8 - 9

history.text: Identified based on statements by her father

At the age of 80, Leonor Leme testified in the canonization process of San José de Anchieta, during which it was recorded that she was originally from Óbidos, Portugal. She lived a long life and passed away in <htdate0>
Confirmed through statements from Leonor and her children
Confirmed in her mother's inventory

families.name: Descendants of Bráz Esteves and Leonor Leme

history.text: As Lucrécia Leme was born in Portugal, we have chosen to begin the history of the Leme family in São Vicente with their children

A misunderstanding by a distant descendant, Pedro Dias Paes (Leme), incorrectly identified her husband as her uncle. This issue was analyzed in detail by Luiz P. M. de Castro, with additional data about her grandfather’s generation added on this page

source.text: de Castro, Luiz P. M., pp. 8 - 9

history.text: This relationship is confirmed through the couple’s inventories, a diligence submitted to the Santo Ofício by a descendant, and the de Genere process of her grandson, Reverend Father João Leite da Silva

source.text: Torre do Tombo, Tribunal do Santo Ofício: Conselho Geral, Habilitações, Pedro, mç. 25, doc. 476, img. 62

history.text: In <htdate0>, Lucrécia’s inventory stated that she had 15 children with her sole husband. This text focuses on the generation associated with São Paulo’s civil wars and the territorial expansion of Brazil

Pedro Dias (Paes) is confirmed as their child through the couple’s inventories, a diligence submitted to the Santo Ofício by a descendant, and the de Genere process of his grandson, Reverend Father João Leite da Silva

source.text: Torre do Tombo, Tribunal do Santo Ofício: Conselho Geral, Habilitações, Pedro, mç. 25, doc. 476, img. 62

history.text: Pedro T. de A. Paes Leme describes Pedro Dias as someone who "held various important positions in the republic many times" (ocupou os cargos da república muitas vezes). Multiple references to a Pedro Dias, believed to be him, can be found in São Paulo’s historical records

source.text: Paes Leme, Pedro T. de A., Vol. III, pp.57
Atas de São Paulo, Volume II

history.text: This relationship is confirmed through the couple’s inventories, a diligence submitted to the Santo Ofício by a descendant, and the de Genere process of her son, Reverend Father João Leite da Silva

source.text: Torre do Tombo, Tribunal do Santo Ofício: Conselho Geral, Habilitações, Pedro, mç. 25, doc. 476, img. 62

history.text: Maria’s life and ancestry were affected by genealogical falsifications. Her father, Paschoal Leite, was renamed by Pedro T. de A. Paes Leme as Paschoal Leite Furtado and described as a nobleman. However, witnesses in the canonization process of Saint José de Anchieta revealed that Paschoal was a descendant of Indigenous people

Ongoing research has mapped the genetic lineage and is showing that his great-grandmother, Maria de Faria, carried the matrilineal haplogroup A2. This shows that her children inherited Indigenous mitochondrial DNA

Interestingly, approximately 140 years after his family may have witnessed the Treaty of Tordesillas and possibly aided the Iberian Crowns in colonizing the Americas (Abya Yala), one of his descendants married an individual from the Indigenous population they had colonized
This relationship is confirmed through the couple’s inventories, a diligence submitted to the Santo Ofício by a descendant

source.text: Torre do Tombo, Tribunal do Santo Ofício: Conselho Geral, Habilitações, Pedro, mç. 25, doc. 476, img. 62

history.text: This relationship is confirmed through the couple’s inventories, and his de Genere

source.text: Torre do Tombo, Tribunal do Santo Ofício: Conselho Geral, Habilitações, Pedro, mç. 25, doc. 476, img. 62

history.text: Reverend Father João Leite da Silva had his limpieza de sangre included in the process of nobility justification for Pedro Dias Paes (Leme), a descendant of his brother, Fernão Dias Paes. However, due to an error, he was incorrectly listed in a genealogical tree presented in a diligence to become a Familiar of the Santo Oficio as being his mother’s husband, rather than her son

source.text: Torre do Tombo, Tribunal do Santo Ofício: Conselho Geral, Habilitações, Pedro, mç. 25, doc. 476, img. 62

history.text: Fernão Dias Paes is a prominent figure in colonial history, widely studied for his significant contributions across various aspects of colonial life. However, some works about his life contain inaccuracies. For instance, Diogo Luiz de A. P. de Vasconcellos highlights errors in the writings of Pedro T. de A. Paes Leme, such as the false claim that Fernão lived into his eighties. This error can be corrected by examining his parents' inventories and the record of his death in <htdate0>

source.text: de Vasconcellos, Diogo Luiz de A. P., pp. 31 - 44
Paes Leme, Pedro T. de A., Vol. III, pp. 61 - 78

history.text: Fernão played an active role in the Paulista Civil War, initially supporting the expulsion of the Jesuits, though he later advocated for their return. During the conflict, he allied with the Pires family, which led to defamatory attacks from the Camargo family. The Camargos accused him of being Jewish because of his marriage to a member of the Fernandes family. However, this accusation was proven false

source.text: Torre do Tombo, Tribunal do Santo Ofício: Conselho Geral, Habilitações, Pedro, mç. 25, doc. 476, img. 43

history.text: In his later years, Fernão led an expedition (bandeira) in <htdate0> in search of emeralds. While he did not succeed in finding them, he discovered tourmalines, a less valuable mineral

Recent ongoing research suggests that both Fernão and his wife possessed Indigenous mitochondrial DNA. However, this did not prevent him from engaging in aggressive actions against Indigenous communities. During his expeditions, he enslaved thousands of people and destroyed numerous villages. Among his notable conquests were three Indigenous kingdoms that had resisted colonial forces for some time. After defeating these kingdoms, he relocated more than 5,000 Indigenous people to the area now known as São Paulo. Contemporary chroniclers note that his intention was to deliver them to missionaries to be educated according to Christian principles

source.text: de Vasconcellos, Diogo Luiz de A. P., pp. 31 - 44
Paes Leme, Pedro T. de A., Vol. III, pp. 63 - 65

history.text: Confirmed through the baptism of their son

source.text: Torre do Tombo, Tribunal do Santo Ofício: Conselho Geral, Habilitações, Pedro, mç. 25, doc. 476, img. 159

history.text: Recent research has revealed that Maria Garcia also had Indigenous mitochondrial DNA, specifically haplogroup C1b (subgroup). As a result, their children inherited Indigenous mitochondrial DNA as well
Confirmed through his baptism and records related to his own son

source.text: Torre do Tombo, Tribunal do Santo Ofício: Conselho Geral, Habilitações, Pedro, mç. 25, doc. 476, img. 62, 159

history.text: Confirmed through the matrimonial dispensation of Maximiano de Oliveira Leite and Ignácia de Arruda

The story of Garcia Roiz Paes is a striking example of how the effects of war and defamation can persist through generations. Even when the defamer asks for forgiveness for the lies they spread, the consequences remain, reinforcing the idea that the first casualty of war is always the truth

source.text: Torre do Tombo, Tribunal do Santo Ofício: Conselho Geral, Habilitações, Pedro, mç. 25, doc. 476, img. 5, 42, 48, 95, 111

history.text: The defamation against Garcia Roiz Paes began with the actions of his great-uncle, André Fernandes, during a conflict with the Camargo family. As a result, his maternal grandmother, Maria Betim —André Fernandes' sister— also became a target of slander. Later, Maria Betim's husband, Garcia Roiz Velho, was accused of favoring the Pires family. Initially, he was defamed for marrying Maria Betim. Subsequently, a rumor spread that he had not become a priest because he was Jewish. However, the truth was that he had not joined the priesthood because of a homicide and his marriage

source.text: Torre do Tombo, Tribunal do Santo Ofício: Conselho Geral, Habilitações, Pedro, mç. 25, doc. 476, img. 4, 24, 28 - 30, 42, 44 - 45, 47 - 49, 66 - 69, 71, 94, 110

history.text: Following this pattern, Garcia Roiz Paes' father was also the target of similar accusations. Over successive generations, the family faced repeated defamation, culminating in accusations that Garcia Roiz Paes himself was a "cristão novo" (New Christian), influenced by the lingering slander against his maternal grandmother

source.text: Torre do Tombo, Tribunal do Santo Ofício: Conselho Geral, Habilitações, Pedro, mç. 25, doc. 476, img. 4, 24, 28 - 30, 42, 44 - 45, 47 - 49, 66 - 69, 71, 94, 110
Torre do Tombo, Mesa da Consciência e Ordens, Habilitações para a Ordem de Cristo, Letra G, mç. 6, n.º 66

history.text: Garcia Roiz Paes, Guarda-Mor Geral of the Golden Mines, passed away on
According to the records of his son’s habilitation

source.text: Torre do Tombo, Tribunal do Santo Ofício: Conselho Geral, Habilitações, Pedro, mç. 25, doc. 476, img. 47, 62, 82, 134, 231

history.text: Ignacio Dias Velho passed away prematurely after suffering an accident just a few days after being approved to become a priest. As a result of this incident, he was never ordained

source.text: Torre do Tombo, Tribunal do Santo Ofício: Conselho Geral, Habilitações, Pedro, mç. 25, doc. 476, img. 7, 42 - 44, 50 - 51, 62, 88, 121, 231

history.text: A detailed study of Lucrécia Leme Borges de Serqueira has not yet been conducted as part of this project. Therefore, we limit ourselves to reproducing the information regarding her family relationships as documented in the habilitation diligence of her son

source.text: Torre do Tombo, Tribunal do Santo Ofício, Conselho Geral, Habilitações, Garcia, mç. 1, doc. 7, img. 5, 8

source.text: Torre do Tombo, Tribunal do Santo Ofício, Conselho Geral, Habilitações, Garcia, mç. 1, doc. 7, img. 5, 8

source.text: Torre do Tombo, Tribunal do Santo Ofício, Conselho Geral, Habilitações, Garcia, mç. 1, doc. 7, img. 5, 8

history.text: The habilitation process of Garcia Roiz Paes Leme for Familiar of the Holy Office was relatively straightforward due to the extensive prior investigation conducted into his ancestry, particularly regarding his uncle, Pedro Dias Paes (Leme)

source.text: Torre do Tombo, Tribunal do Santo Ofício, Conselho Geral, Habilitações, Garcia, mç. 1, doc. 7

history.text:
Key Points from the Diligence:
  • Absence of Rumors or Bad Reputation:No rumors or accusations of bad reputation were found regarding Garcia Roiz Paes Leme, as earlier clarifications had already been established during his uncle's process (Torre do Tombo, Tribunal do Santo Ofício, Conselho Geral, Habilitações, Garcia, mç. 1, doc. 7, img. 3).
  • References to Family Members Accepted by the Holy Office: In his account of family background, Garcia highlighted that both his uncle, Pedro Dias Paes Leme, and his cousin, Roberto C. Ribeiro, had also been recognized as Familiars of the Holy Office (Torre do Tombo, Tribunal do Santo Ofício, Conselho Geral, Habilitações, Garcia, mç. 1, doc. 7, img. 5-6 ).
  • Questions and Inquiries:The diligence includes a series of questions and inquiries conducted during the process. (Torre do Tombo, Tribunal do Santo Ofício, Conselho Geral, Habilitações, Garcia, mç. 1, doc. 7, img. 7 - 65 ).

The habilitation diligences of Pedro Dias Paes as a Familiar of the Holy Office, alongside those of his cousin Domingos Jorge da Silva, underscore the use of defamation against their ancestors during the Paulista Civil War—a common practice in those times

source.text: Torre do Tombo, Tribunal do Santo Ofício: Conselho Geral, Habilitações, Pedro, mç. 25, doc. 476
Torre do Tombo. Tribunal do Santo Oficio, Conselho Geral, Habilitações, Domingos, mç. 21, doc. 419

history.text:
We have already presented various documental references and information about the ancestors of Pedro Dias Paes. This section focuses on mapping the content and highlighting some important excerpts:
  • Family Defamation:At the beginning of the document, there is a summary of the "conversions" resulting from defamatory claims against the families Fernandes, Leme, Paes, Garcia Velho, and Tavares (Torre do Tombo, Tribunal do Santo Ofício: Conselho Geral, Habilitações, Pedro, mç. 25, doc. 476, img. 3 - 8).
  • Testimony of priest Frei Francisco de S. José:
    • "ouvira dizer que um Francisco de Camargo, por alcunha o Tigre, homem conhecidamente de má lingoa, dissera em certa occasião, que havia de ir pôr ... judeo de André Fernandes ascendente de Garcia Roiz Paes" (Torre do Tombo, Tribunal do Santo Ofício: Conselho Geral, Habilitações, Pedro, mç. 25, doc. 476, img. 42).
  • Testimony of Joseph Mascarenhas:
    • "Digo e afirmo que o Dor Pº Dias Paes, quer por parte paterna, quer por parte materna puro, e de limpo sangue sem raça alguma de Judeu, Mouro, Mouriço, ou outra qualquer nação infecta... Bem he verdade que nos annos antigos houve uma fama não constante, nem comũa por falta de fundamentos, mais que do ódio" (Torre do Tombo, Tribunal do Santo Ofício: Conselho Geral, Habilitações, Pedro, mç. 25, doc. 476, img. 128 - 129).
  • Fernandes Descendants and Their Reputation::
    • "a descendência dos Fernandes entraram muitos nas ordens Terceiras, e na irmandade da Misericórdia onde se apuram p vas gerações a limpeza destes odernarao se de sacerdotes depois da infâmia, o padre António Soares, filho de António Francisco de Abreo, bisneto por parte paterna de Baltazar Fernandes, irmão do Capitão André Fernandes, o P Frei Franco Bicudo, religioso de Nosssa Senhora do Carmo Conven.. de São Paulo, filho de Bar de Godoi Bicudo, bisneto por parte materna de Baltazar Fernandes, irmão do Cap. André Fernandes, o padre Bªr de Godoy Bicudo, filho do capitão Bernardo de Campos Bicudo terceiro neto por parte materna do .. Bar Fernades. O Pe Victorino de Borba Leite, filho do tenente general Mel de Borba Gato de huma irmã do Capm Guarda mor Garcia Roiz Paes"
    (Torre do Tombo, Tribunal do Santo Ofício: Conselho Geral, Habilitações, Pedro, mç. 25, doc. 476, img. 49 ).
  • Probatory Documentation: Additional evidence is presented in images 159–160 of the same document, following the testimonies (Torre do Tombo, Tribunal do Santo Ofício: Conselho Geral, Habilitações, Pedro, mç. 25, doc. 476, img. 159 - 160).
  • Investigation of His Wife:The diligences also include information about Francisca Joaquina Forjas Pereira, wife of Pedro Dias Paes (Torre do Tombo, Tribunal do Santo Ofício: Conselho Geral, Habilitações, Pedro, mç. 25, doc. 476, img. 160 - 231 ).

An important aspect of this investigation is the analysis of Pedro Dias Paes' nobility justification, where an incorrect patrilineal lineage is presented. This reveals inconsistencies in the use of surnames over centuries. Although the document claims that Pedro and his ancestors consistently used "Leme" as a surname, earlier records do not confirm this practice

source.text: de Castro, Luiz P. M., pp. 4-9

exercise_v2.question: Do the first generatsions of Lem family have a lot of data?
exercise_v2.additionalInfo: Unfortunately, we know few about the first generations of this family, this conduct us to consider the existence of Maertin Lem (I) and Maertin Lem (II) as independent people.

exercise_v2.question: Trets were signed with witness?
exercise_v2.additionalInfo: In addition to the monarcs, the treatments also had witnesses, they were named noble, that also signed documents.

exercise_v2.question: Do not Europeans had relationship with indigenous?
exercise_v2.additionalInfo: Some old publications try to force this idea, but genetic map and ancient documentation are proofing they are wrong.

exercise_v2.question: Is the distance of 370 leguas of Tordesillas that split the world from Cabo Verde Islands (Biblioteca Nacional de Portugal - BNP, BN MS. 5, n.º 25, F. 3v, 4r, 5r) in kilometers equal to x = 5.5 quilômetros1 légua 370 léguas = 2035.0 kilômetros?
exercise_v2.additionalInfo: Yes, using (F. 8) together the proportionality constant 5.5 quilômetros1 légua, we arrive to the result 2035.0 kilometers from Cabo Verde Island.
